mainClaim: Universal healthcare systems deliver better health outcomes at lower costs than market-based systems
evidence: Comprehensive analysis of 30 OECD countries shows universal systems spend 40% less per capita ($5,697 vs $11,945 in U.S.) while achieving better outcomes: 4.2 years longer life expectancy, 50% lower infant mortality, 35% lower chronic disease burden. JAMA study found U.S. administrative costs consume 34% of healthcare spending vs 17% in universal systems. No medical bankruptcies in universal systems vs 530,000/year in U.S.
supportingPoints: Preventive care access reduces expensive emergency treatments
Single-payer eliminates insurance profit margins and complexity
Negotiating power reduces drug prices 60-80% vs U.S. levels
Universal coverage improves productivity - workers less afraid to leave jobs
limitations: Transition costs and disruption significant. Wait times for non-urgent procedures can be longer. Taxation increases required. Cultural/political barriers in U.S. are substantial. Quality of implementation varies by country.
